awd_titl_txt: REU SITE:  Integrative approaches to studying recognition systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) Site award to Tufts University, located in Medford, MA, will support the training of 12 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019- 2021. The REU program, focused on integrative approaches to studying recognition systems in cells, organisms, and populations, will provide students the opportunity to work closely on collaborative, interdisciplinary projects combining faculty expertise in biochemistry, genetics, development, endocrinology, neurobiology, behavior, ecology, and conservation. Students will work with two mentors to design and conduct independent projects. In addition to research, the program includes weekly discussions, seminars, field trips, and two student symposia. The goals of this summer program are to increase student proficiency in biological research and collaborative skills, to educate and inspire students toward future research careers, and to develop student ability to effectively communicate scientific results. Accordingly, seminars are focused on proficiency in science/communication of results, scientific ethics and the responsible conduct of research, and career development. Participants are selected from a broad undergraduate applicant pool, and preference is given to students from underrepresented groups and those who might not have research opportunities at their home institution (e.g., community college students).

It is anticipated that a total of 36 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. The Department of Biology has a long-standing commitment to mentoring undergraduates in research, and a strong track record of highly productive interdisciplinary research collaborations. Student-mentor relationships typically extend long beyond the research experience and are facilitated via electronic networking tools. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences and/or in scientific papers. A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://ase.tufts.edu/biology/undergraduate/research/reu.htm, or by contacting Dr. Phil Starks at REU@tufts.edu.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An award was granted to the Biology Department at Tufts University to provide a 10-week research training program for 12 students each summer from 2019 to 2022. (The award period was extended due to pandemic-related complications.) The summer program, titled "Integrative Approaches to Studying Recognition Systems in Cells, Organisms, and Populations," offered students the chance to engage in collaborative, interdisciplinary projects combining biochemistry, genetics, development, endocrinology, neurobiology, animal behavior, plant ecology, and conservation biology.

Students worked with two mentors, one serving as the primary mentor, to design and conduct independent projects at the forefront of various research fields. Beyond their research involvement, the program included weekly discussions, seminars, field trips, and two student symposia. The goals were to enhance students' proficiency in biological research and collaboration, inspire them toward future research careers, and develop their ability to effectively communicate scientific results. Seminars focused on science communication, the responsible conduct of research, and career development.

Participants were selected from a diverse pool of undergraduate applicants, with a commitment to providing research opportunities for students traditionally underrepresented in science and those lacking similar opportunities at their home institutions, especially community college students. The Tufts University Department of Biology has a longstanding commitment to mentoring undergraduates in research and boasts a strong track record of productive interdisciplinary research collaborations. Student-mentor relationships often extend beyond the research experience, facilitated by electronic networking tools.

Participants provided frequent feedback on the program, actively helping to refine its approach. Program information was assessed through various methods, including an REU common assessment tool. (For more information, contact Phil Starks at REU@tufts.edu.)

Science thrives on continuous input and innovation, and training the next generation of scientists is crucial to sustaining this progress. A significant barrier is the 'identity' issue, where students may struggle to envision themselves as scientists. Our 10-week NSF-funded REU program addressed this by immersing students in all aspects of the scientific process.

Our expanding biology department at Tufts University focuses on topics across all biological levels. By framing projects associated with the REU program within a recognition system theme, we reinforced the continuity of biological research and enabled students to explore diverse systems using varied techniques.

Between 2019 and 2022, we received 465 applications for 35 positions. Most of our participants self-identified as belonging to historically underrepresented groups in science. They came from colleges across the country and formed collaborative scientific communities on our Medford campus. Our faculty guided these students in exploring interests across biological fields, from molecular biology to population dynamics.

To achieve our goal of providing a high-quality research experience, we focused on training students to become independent scientists, fostering a sense of community, encouraging project ownership, and offering career development tools. Specifically, we:

  • Provided resources to integrate participants into the local community, trained them in conceptual and technical skills necessary for independent research (including project design, data collection, analysis, and presentation), and taught critical communication skills for scientific success.
  • Cultivated a sense of community by organizing educational field trips, hosting weekly working dinner meetings, housing students together on campus, and welcoming them into our homes.
  • Encouraged project ownership by having students give mid-program presentations and lead lab tours.
  • Guided students in identifying suitable graduate programs, building resumes, and introduced them to a panel of professionals from various scientific fields to help them understand potential career paths in science.

In addition to general and field-specific scientific training, participants received financial support and career development advice, culminating in a panel discussion on alternative careers in science featuring educators, healthcare practitioners, and representatives from governmental, non-governmental, and industry sectors.

Survey responses indicated that students gained significant scientific knowledge and skills from participating in the program. Of the 35 participants, many are currently working in research, have completed or are enrolled in advanced degree programs, or are pursuing careers in healthcare. Numerous participants have been authors on conference posters, presentations, and peer-reviewed publications, with several more contributing to manuscripts in preparation.
